abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Urban Sector Development
            Reform Project for Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: project implementation was
            successful owing to the high commitment of the executing
            agency (EA), especially the central project management unit
            (CPMU), urban local government (ULGs), and the key role of
            the Inter-Ministerial Steering Committee (IMSC). The
            creation of a platform for local governance reforms works
            best through a combination of: (a) legally binding
            regulations, (b) adequate institutional arrangements, (c)
            actual practices, and (d) strengthening the capacity of
            "champions", supported by a system of incentives
            and disincentives. Lessons learned and experiences of local
            governments should have been considered as inputs to the
            relevant national legislations, so that the reform agenda is
            tailored to local situation and realistic. Peer-to-peer
            learning and on-the-job training are two capacity building
            schemes that can be more effective than traditional, formal
            training. Training with outputs that are to be implemented
            by the ULGs under the project was quite effective to achieve
            the key performance indicators (KPIs). Implementation of
            subprojects will be more successful if aspects of eventual
            long term operation (especially management set-up and
            funding) are considered from the preparation. Capacity
            building activities should be given more attention; this
            includes the participation of agency leaders (Kepala Dinas)
            and local parliament members. Funding of local subprojects
            through subsidiary loan agreements (SLAs) tends to be
            convoluted and protracted; future projects should consider
            an alternative funding mechanism that is among others a
            financial intermediary facility when numerous local
            governments are involved. When determining the readiness for
            implementation during the appraisal process, one key aspect
            to expedite the start-up of project implementation is to
            promote the advance procurement prior to loan effectiveness.
            The trade-off of benefits between a project being open to
            all ULGs and regional clustering should be considered very
            carefully at appraisal, bearing in mind the inefficiencies
            that can result from regional scattering of project
            locations. Project design should also: (a) design a
            mechanism, and (b) assign resources for dealing with
            unforeseen developments, for example, (1) changes in
            commitment of ULGs, or (2) requests from further ULGs to
            join the project.
